awd_titl_txt: Pulses of Biogenic Nitrogen Cycling Lead to Atmospheric-Based Nutrient Spiraling in Southern California
awd_abstract_narration:
The cycling of nitrogen in arid lands, deserts, and areas with limited water and frequent high temperatures is challenging to study and does not fit within the current understanding of other areas such as forests or grasslands. In arid lands, nitrogen concentrations are generally low and many biological processes are limited by nitrogen availability during wet periods.  However, many arid land ecosystems also exhibit high rates of nitrogen loss more characteristic of areas with a nitrogen abundance.  During wet periods soils may emit high nitrogen concentrations. Because of these nitrogen pulses, arid lands may have an important role in atmospheric chemistry although the magnitudes or fate of emissions are not well known.  Return of the soil nitrogen pulses to the soil may be a previously unaccounted nutrient source contributing to downwind nitrogen deposition.  New research directed to characterizing arid land nitrogen dynamics across landscapes may resolve these apparent contradictions, contribute to more comprehensive understanding, and improve understanding of the broad-scale effects of nitrogen enrichment. The findings will be communicated to the federal and state agencies that are directly affected by atmospheric nitrogen including Joshua Tree National Park.  Training opportunities, targeted for underrepresented graduate and undergraduate students, include tools for trace gases, isotopes, genomes, and modeling.  The results will be communicated to the local community through UC Cooperative Extension and an annual public lecture series that targets K-12 educators throughout the region.  

This project will develop and test a hypothesis of pulse-induced nutrient spiraling to explain the landscape distribution of nitrogen concentrations and sources in southern California.  The central hypothesis borrows from nutrient dynamics in stream systems where movement downstream leads to biogeochemical ?spirals?, as nutrients cycle from dissolved and biotic forms.  In arid lands, it is hypothesized that soil pulses of gaseous nitrogen emissions coupled with atmospheric transport and deposition forms such a spiral and propagates nitrogen enrichment across a landscape.   This hypothesis will be evaluated across a transect of decreasing nitrogen deposition extending from Riverside, CA to the eastern edge of Joshua Tree National Park where replicated experiments will be conducted that assess soil nitrogen pulses and identifies their sources through isotopic and genomic tools. These experiments will test predictions that pulses of soil nitrogen emissions have characteristic isotopic signatures and increasingly dominate soil nitrogen content downwind from urban sources.  The experimental results will be used to inform a regional atmospheric transport and chemistry model that will simulate nitrogen dynamics throughout southern California.  The model simulations will further test predictions that soil pulse emissions can influence atmospheric nitrogen chemistry and subsequent nitrogen deposition.

por.por_cntn:
Cities are a prominent source of atmospheric nitrogen pollution and the hinterland ecosystems downwind of many urban centers experience elevated rates of nitrogen deposition. One consequence of this increased nutrient input could be increased emissions from soils to the atmosphere of nitrogen gasses. This ?recycled? nitrogen may further magnify and extend the influence of urbanization on their hinterlands, in a sense creating a spiral in the direction of the predominant wind flows. To test this hypothesis, we directed our research efforts to novel landscape field experiments of soil responses to wetting and nitrogen additions distributed across a nitrogen deposition gradient. Over three years we conducted a series of experiment campaigns that led to more than 29,000 individual measurements of soil nitrogen emissions. These measurements were distributed across seasons, five sites comprising a nitrogen deposition gradient, and featured combinations of nutrient and resource amendments. As part of these experiments we characterized trace gas nitrogen emission dynamics, assessed isotopic transformations, and characterized soil genomic distributions and dynamics. We placed the experiments in the context of long-term monitoring of atmospheric and soil conditions. We extended the experiments through new model applications and assessments of satellite based imagery. Complementing these core research activities we have provided extensive training opportunities, conducted workshops, engaged with stakeholders, and disseminated our findings in support of our broader impact goals. 

Significant results from our project have been generated through both field experiments, modeling activities, and synthesis. A key finding from the project has been the discovery of unprecedented rates of soil nitrogen gas emissions following wetting at desert sites in our study area that differed primarily in N deposition. Contrary to our hypothesis that increased N deposition would alleviate nitrogen limitation of emissions, we found that both nitrogen gas emissions were lower at the High than at the Low nitrogen pollution site. Possibly, differences in plant N uptake, soil pH, and/or microbial nitrogen use between sites may constrain nitrogen availability and help explain why higher rates of atmospheric nitrogen deposition did not translate into higher soil nitrogen emissions. Despite strong differences in microbial community structure between sites and in response to wetting, emission patterns could not be explained by the measured microbial metrics. To assess the potential contribution of nitrogen gas emission pulses to desert nitrogen budgets, we used a simplified and conservative upscaling and estimated the potential nitrogen emissions to represent up to 49% of atmospheric nitrogen inputs. These results are surprising and also provide key support for our core research hypothesis, that soil nitrogen emissions may contribute to downwind deposition. We have translated these results into new modeling capabilities and identify regional consequences of nitrogen emissions. A significant result has been the outcomes of new atmospheric  modeling and satellite nitrogen pollution observations. Through analyses of satellite data we could identify regional increases in nitrogen pollution following rain events, consistent with soil emission trajectory. Our results suggest that the soil nitrogen gas emissions have a large potential to impact air quality and should be considered in the future emission control strategies. Our results have estimated that soil derived nitrogen gas emissions are an important source of atmospheric nitrogen pollution in California, contributing ∼40% on a state average and more than 50% in rural regions. Our results highlight the benefits of limiting soil derived nitrogen emissions to help improve air quality and human health in rural California. In synthesizing our findings, we have developed new landscape models describing soil N trace gas dynamics and used these models to assess nutrient spiraling metrics across our N deposition gradient. We have also developed a new framework for evaluating urban-hinterland interactions that couples the spatial distribution of ecosystems with ecological and societal systems that influence these distributions.
